@sanity_io  I U make image hosting so complicated?

I fell back to my default headless cms @contentful because getting images into their CDN and a resizable URL out is so much simpler there... https://t.co/9C5LZ9Hcs4
@NativeWired Yeah, I guess in that case only https://t.co/7YQpdLeYW7 will help ...

Started to work on the webpage for the next @TechWomenNorway event, and basing it on the DevConf theme by @3rdwave_themes, which is really well done!
https://t.co/6AWC6qFgTl
@alex_schl @building_iot Definitely one of the tough questions in especially for embedded development ...

@emsuiko Sending a big hug,
I'm sure you'll get this sorted out!

@even @sanity_io I looked into https://t.co/kTnbL45Oev to do this, since it offers that feature: https://t.co/TI1ODEtpXn

I registered on https://t.co/kTnbL45Oev, and discovered that I need a "project", which I can only get by installing the CLI ...

@even @sanity_io I need to initialize a project in my source code repo as well, to launch the Sanity Studio, which I did, however, it offered me no way to upload images...

I actually needed to construct REST requests to upload pictures (https://t.co/H4Sl8iiaeS) ...
@even @sanity_io ... for which I need to find out my space ID, get an API key, find the files on my computer (which I need to download first).
@even @sanity_io This is way to much plumbing, on @contentful it's easy as 1-2-3: create space, import images (even from URLs), publish. Boom: I have a CDN URL to the image with scaling capabilities.
@even @sanity_io HTH, happy to answer more questions, here or in a call.
@kmelve @even @sanity_io @contentful Can you share a YouTube link? The text is not recognizable on Twitter: https://t.co/WPXs9lvWYc
@kmelve @even @sanity_io @contentful Thanks!

@kmelve @even @sanity_io @contentful Yeah, and I totally get, that my use-case is not the most common one. 

I actually like the approach of defining the schema in code so it can be versioned (and I can create internal tooling of the schema).

Great work on #Iot interoperability:
The Web of Things (WoT) Thing Description is a W3C proposed recommendation for a formal model and a common representation which describes the metadata and interfaces of a Thing: https://t.co/zkhMyV2DSA
I had a very memorable experience last year, you should definitely apply! https://t.co/MbkxkslMYz

@kmelve @even @sanity_io @contentful Thanks to this I moved the site over to https://t.co/KSzTwLjMvS, wasn't too hard since I knew how the config should look like.

Maybe think about provide a TypeScript library to construct the config, that way it would be much easier to know which values are allowed...

Always was a big fan of @greenkeeperio and did pay for their services. I'm sorry to see them go üò¢.
But I trust the people @snyksec, so the migration is a no-brainer for me.
https://t.co/IjZQmfLm8q https://t.co/kgz5RrrUmD

@PatrickHeneise @greenkeeperio @snyksec Yes, true. Coming from  $399 / year to $9,588 is a 2400% price increase, just to get dependency updates.

This will be a hard sell, but you could just look at how many PRs in your repos are labeled with #greenkeeper and calculate what it would cost to do this work manually.

Hei followers with GIS knowledge: I've implemented an algorithm to approximate locations of cell towers based on reported device geo locations. Does it make sense to do it this way?

Interactive Demo (click to start adding markers): https://t.co/OvcX80Zucq https://t.co/cn9weRuJio

Source: https://t.co/2vivGxHufX

Demo and above GIF are using 5km min cell radius and P=0.9.
Today is Purge Day for corporates. https://t.co/gwwygDybOk
@stefanjudis Oh, good luck with your next adventure!

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets Thing is, I see a lot of new cell ids, which are not even resolved by commercial providers that we use, so this is made especially for these situations where new networks are being built, or set up ad-hoc (like for trade shows), or have rapidly changing cell ideas (e.g. China).

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets We don't get cell tower locations for free and it would be a massive effort to acquire those for every local provider, and even if, it would be only available for internal use. We can't put this database in an open-source project.

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets The Mozilla thing is cool, thanks for sharing, but has no commercial offering or SLA, so it's not the simple plug-and-play solution I am looking for, but it's cool that it can be run open-source.

I'll definitely check their database against the cells we have on record.
... and cache management is a form of cash management. https://t.co/bBSF3xVh7A

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets MLS is not generally available, so I somehow doubt that they have a wide, worldwide adoption. 

Running an instance is then the only option, but is not serverless, so costs will be higher. https://t.co/b0MeTjGq1D
@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets I already use this data through https://t.co/MgxqLmnL7g.
From *the* authority on everything #remote comes this great guide with tons of resources: https://t.co/gGtYvxGKyV

@RealIvanSanchez @opencellid @UnwiredLabs This sounds viable but I have to verify how long it takes for new location data to be available.

This also exposes meta data about devices (locations, movement) to a third party which is not acceptable for everyone.
.@Technoport_  2020 in #Trondheim üá≥üá¥ is cancelled because of #covid19: https://t.co/bMf3I7ygh8 https://t.co/288id8cNC9
Be more like this dude! https://t.co/fJluvoqPUn
@orless From the #nrf9160, which has GPS, and if this cell has not previously been visited by a device, I query @UnwiredLabs and @rxnetworks.
@RealIvanSanchez Thanks for pointing out @turfjs, it was easy to use it for calculating the distance with and I understand that it's now more accurate.
@RealIvanSanchez @turfjs However your example does not sort out outliers (P=.9) anymore when calculating the center of the positions. Do you have a recommendation how to do that with turf?

And here is the example of cells that were not know to @unwiredlabs API during our embedded world demo, and how this approach helps to locate them roughly:
https://t.co/Tk7BZSS4TI https://t.co/DVXVu5bFpd

@RealIvanSanchez @turfjs Thanks for these pointers, i'll look into them. 

For now I think the solution works okay, especially since I only want to roughly want to locate a device based on it's cell and most cells can be located through UnwiredLabs.
@RealIvanSanchez @turfjs In these scenarios, where we only have one cellID there is no certainty about the device location on a meter level right now any way.
@signicat I'm seeing timeouts right now: https://t.co/ACJaCsvoJj
Day 1 of working from home: I am going to pick up extra hardware from the office (monitors), because I expect this to go on for quite some time.

@thatengjayson Monitors,
emphasis on plural (3 in my case) ;-)

@thatengjayson This is my setup: https://t.co/VZ7iMU4mPT

I tried huge and wide single setups, but I like that setup most.
Get an @theRoostStand (or similar), external keyboard and mouse / trackpad this will help to work with a setup like this. https://t.co/ZNVzACHc1T

First day working from home and the office is empty. We have @NordicTweets meetings already running pretty flawlessly ... Everyone here already has experience working from home because of kids, flex-time, etc and has headset+webcam. Also broadband at home is standard here. üá≥üá¥
@datenreisender @theRoostStand @rradczewski @SoCraTes_Conf I have a spare one at home, in case you need it.
@datenreisender @theRoostStand @rradczewski @SoCraTes_Conf Yes, we also have two brands and they are exactly the same. I wonder who is the OEM for that :-)

@meikeco Oh?
Hoffe alles is soweit in Ordnung?

@thatengjayson Personally I have the best experience with a focused are in the middle, so a 24" screen with 1920x1200 is best, larger screens can usually only be split in the middle, but not in three parts.

It's fun and you have a quicker way to initiate a chat (because you see when they are at their desk).

I'm one of those who can be working remote for weeks without missing real world human interaction.

Great call for a productive mindset when building software: build on top of existing code, instead of trashing what has been done by others.

@pati_gallardo Looks like they just added CloudFlare and DNS propagation takes a while.

The hotfix is to have a static HTML under the old DNS name and redirect all traffic to a new hostname, which serves the site through the CDN.

From 1500 to 1600 (Oslo time, CET) every day I will do an open coffee hangout, fell free to jump in and let's talk about tech and other interesting stuff!

Links to the hangouts will be posted below.

@KlaraMiffili Going down to individual tickets IMO makes no sense because as you rightfully see work for a whole thing is hard to separate per issues.

You need to tell the client how much time was spent by the team on each feature per sprint, more granularity is useless bureaucracy.

@alterisian @steely_glint @AdSidera IME Twitter works best for connecting speakers and the audience virtually, typically during and after the conference around a hashtag.

For me no other community lasted past the course of the event, except one community Slack.

@alterisian @steely_glint @AdSidera For that a live video chat works best, Google Hangouts is free, @zoom_us not but allows recording and has IMO better video quality and better pre-scheduling of meetings (e.g. you can stream recording of talks and then have the speaker be in the room for Q&A).
@KlaraMiffili https://t.co/zmRT3IEcFX
@alterisian @steely_glint @AdSidera @zoom_us Not everyone is comfortable with being watched all the time.
@alterisian @steely_glint @AdSidera @zoom_us This makes sense, also to conserve bandwidth for attendees with slower connections.

@mehulmpt What does redux solve for you?
What is a Middleware for you?
@mehulmpt Why are you using redux to manage the application state and not React?
@acemarke Thanks, will have a look at it!
@NicoleRauch Thanks for confirming that!

@NicoleRauch Yesterday in the remote chat we had the questions why you still should learn redux these days.

IMO because a lot of existing projects use it, but I would strongly advise against using it, because it's a big overhead and I mostly see downsides of using it.

@NicoleRauch ... and I do have worked on data heavy UI apps, but for me having a global state for everything means it's harder for components to evolve individually, it creates often unnecessary cohesion.
